channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: These doctors brought a shuttered L.A. hospital back to life to fight coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: The L.A. Surge Hospital treated a small number of coronavirus patients during the 39 days it was open. But doctors say it saved 'many, many lives,' while restoring their faith in medicine.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. Surge Hospital treated a small number of coronavirus patients during the 39 days it was open. But doctors say it saved 'many, many lives,' while restoring their faith in medicine.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 13: St. Vincent Medical Center located at 2131 West 3rd st. in Los Angeles is back in business to help ease the pressure on local hospitals amid the novel coronavirus pandemic. Staff set up beds and other equipment ready to receive patients with Covid-19 starting Monday. The 266-bed facility will serve as a hospital accepting patients that have tested positive at a different regional hospital that may be at capacity. Los Angeles on Monday, April 13, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Young adults who think 'they are invincible' increasingly infected by coronavirus, Newsom says
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby, Sandhya Kambhampati , Iris Lee
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Monday said the surge in coronavirus cases hitting California was due in part to younger people who might believe "they are invincible" but nonetheless are becoming sick from COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Monday said the surge in coronavirus cases hitting California was due in part to younger people who might believe "they are invincible" but nonetheless are becoming sick from COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: Things looked normal at bars like Lahaina Beach House on Sunday March 15, 2020. Gov. Gavin Newsom called for the closure of bars later that night.

item.title: 13-year-old girl killed in violent carjacking of family van in Pico Rivera
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: The teen was one of four children inside the vehicle when a man jumped in and sped off.
item.content:encoded: The teen was one of four children inside the vehicle when a man jumped in and sped off.

media:content.media:description: Isabella Cortes, 13, died during a violent carjacking in Pico Rivera Sunday July 5, 2020..

item.title: As coronavirus cases surge, L.A. County death toll tops 3,500
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The city-run testing facility at Dodger Stadium was closed Monday. City officials were not immediately available to comment on whether it would be reopened.
item.content:encoded: The city-run testing facility at Dodger Stadium was closed Monday. City officials were not immediately available to comment on whether it would be reopened.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 30, Shoppers, wearing masks to protect themselves from coronavirus, shop on Santee Alley in the Garment District in downtown Los Angeles on June 30, 2020. Masks are required for shopping on Santee Alley and social distancing is advised, but hard to enforce. The shopping area has been open again for the past three weeks. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Top medical officer for California prisons ousted amid worsening coronavirus outbreak
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Kim Christensen
item.description: The move comes amid criticism over the transfer of hundreds of inmates to prisons from a Chino facility reeling from coronavirus infections.
item.content:encoded: The move comes amid criticism over the transfer of hundreds of inmates to prisons from a Chino facility reeling from coronavirus infections.

media:content.media:description: Schaben, Allen J.   CHINO: AUG. 10, 2009: As viewed through the afternoon heat waves, a corrections officer looks out from a tower over barbed wire fences and transport busses at the California Institution For Men State Prison in Chino. California prisons remain on lockdown after Saturday's riot in Chino. On Aug. 8 a violent riot broke out at the California Institution of Men in the West reception facility. About 200 inmates were injured and 30 remain hospitalized with nonlife threatening injuries. Some say the riot is a result of racerelated tensions between Blacks and Latinos.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Newsom, coming under fire, ramps up enforcement and adds counties to watchlist
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: Newsom vows to crack down on restaurants and bars that ignored restrictions over the July 4 weekend. Some critics say it is too little, too late.
item.content:encoded: Newsom vows to crack down on restaurants and bars that ignored restrictions over the July 4 weekend. Some critics say it is too little, too late.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his plan for the gradual reopening of California businesses during a news conference at the Display California store in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday, May 5, 2020. Newsom warned counties that going too far in loosening coronavirus restrictions, could endanger public health. Display California, which sells locally-made items from around the state, is planning to open for curbside service on Friday under upcoming state guidelines. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: L.A. lawmaker tests positive for COVID-19, forcing delay of Assembly legislative session
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: California's state Capitol is closed, and its Assembly leader is delaying hearings after Assemblywoman Autumn Burke and four others test positive for the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: California's state Capitol is closed, and its Assembly leader is delaying hearings after Assemblywoman Autumn Burke and four others test positive for the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: SACRAMENTO CA SEPTEMBER 9, 2019 -- Assemblywoman Autumn Burke (D-Marina del Rey) confers with a colleague during floor debate at the state Capitol on Aug. 29, 2019. (Robert Gourley / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Gimme Shelter: Why it's still really expensive to buy a home in California
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: Neither home prices nor rents have gone down significantly in California despite double-digit unemployment.
item.content:encoded: Neither home prices nor rents have gone down significantly in California despite double-digit unemployment.

media:content.media:description: A home in Palo Alto. Pending sales of previously owned homes rose 21.8% in the Midwest, 9.2% in the South and 9% in the Northeast in February, but fell 4.8% in the West in February, according to the National Assn. of Realtors.

item.title: Crews fire near Gilroy destroys two homes, chars 5,400 acres
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Crews fire ignited about 11:30 a.m. Sunday near Highway 152 in Gilroy and forced dozens of residents to evacuate.
item.content:encoded: The Crews fire ignited about 11:30 a.m. Sunday near Highway 152 in Gilroy and forced dozens of residents to evacuate.

media:content.media:description: A wildfire that broke out Sunday has burned 2,000 acres and destroyed two homes near Gilroy.

item.title: Beaches reopen in L.A., Ventura counties after holiday weekend closure
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Beaches in Los Angeles and Ventura counties were closed for three days in an effort to keep crowds away amid the growing coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: Beaches in Los Angeles and Ventura counties were closed for three days in an effort to keep crowds away amid the growing coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - JULY 06: Peter Gratzinger of Pacific Palisades works his way to the water at Santa Monica State Beach which opened to the public at 5 a.m. Monday, July 6, 2020 after being closed for the three-day Fourth of July weekend. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Soledad fire evacuations lifted as firefighters gain upper hand
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The fire that began around Soledad Canyon Road and the 14 Freeway on Sunday was about 30% contained as of 9 a.m., the L.A. County Fire Department said.
item.content:encoded: The fire that began around Soledad Canyon Road and the 14 Freeway on Sunday was about 30% contained as of 9 a.m., the L.A. County Fire Department said.

media:content.media:description: Firefighter hand crews from Azusa Camp 19 climb the hills to put in line containing the Soledad Fire near Aqua Dulce Monday morning.

item.title: 'All he saw to me was my skin color': Clerk faces backlash from judge's comment
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: Chief judge's comment on race roil court,
item.content:encoded: Chief judge's comment on race roil court,

media:content.media:description: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, CALIF. -- TUESDAY, AUGUST 21, 2018: Photo of U.S. District Judge Cormac J. Carney, 59, a former receiver at UCLA 1980 to 1982, in San Juan Capistrano, Calif., on Aug. 21, 2018. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Women say they were groped, violated by police during L.A. curfew arrests
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Among the ranks of protesters who have filed complaints, joined lawsuits and pushed back against tactics used by area police agencies are women who say they were groped, sexually harassed or inappropriately searched.
item.content:encoded: Among the ranks of protesters who have filed complaints, joined lawsuits and pushed back against tactics used by area police agencies are women who say they were groped, sexually harassed or inappropriately searched.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 05: Portrait of Julia Dupuis, 21, near the corner of 8th and Crenshaw on Sunday, July 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Julia Dupuis says a LAPD officer groped her as she was being arrested on a curfew violation June 2nd. She and others had been participating in a demstration. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California coronavirus spikes worsen over holiday weekend
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Maria L. La Ganga, Kristi Sturgill
item.description: In Los Angeles County, officials said the holiday weekend saw the highest single-day count of new cases since the pandemic began: 3,200 on Friday.
item.content:encoded: In Los Angeles County, officials said the holiday weekend saw the highest single-day count of new cases since the pandemic began: 3,200 on Friday.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA - JULY 05, 2020 - - People walk along the Venice Boardwalk in Venice on July 5, 2020. In what officials have described as an "alarming" increase, hospitalizations of patients with confirmed coronavirus infections in Los Angeles County have jumped 41% in the last three weeks. On Friday, there were 1,947 patients in L.A. County hospitals with confirmed coronavirus infections; seven days earlier, there were 1,717; the week before that, there were 1,426; and the week prior to that, there were 1,383. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus cases hit a record one-day high heading into July 4 weekend
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: The number of hospital patients with confirmed coronavirus infections jumped 41% in the last three weeks in Los Angeles County.
item.content:encoded: The number of hospital patients with confirmed coronavirus infections jumped 41% in the last three weeks in Los Angeles County.

media:content.media:description: UNIVERSAL CITY, CA - JULY 02: A family wearing mask at Universal City Walk Hollywood on Thursday, July 2, 2020 in Universal City, CA. There was very few guests. Gov. Gavin Newsom on Wednesday ordered tougher restrictions on indoor activities for most of the state due to increase in coronavirus cases. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Soledad fire burns 1,100 acres, but firefighters make progress
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: In Santa Clarita, a brushfire that broke out near Soledad Canyon Road jumped the 14 Freeway around 4 p.m. Within hours it had spread to 1,100 acres.
item.content:encoded: In Santa Clarita, a brushfire that broke out near Soledad Canyon Road jumped the 14 Freeway around 4 p.m. Within hours it had spread to 1,100 acres.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES COUNTY, CA - JULY 05: An L.A. County Fire Department helicopter prepares for a water drop on a brushfire burning along the 14 freeway in Agua Dulce on Sunday, July 5, 2020 in Los Angeles County, CA. No structures were threatened so far. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hit-and-run driver kills man who tripped in street after lighting firework, police say
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: A man was struck and killed in a hit-and-run crash Saturday in Lennox when he tripped in the street after lighting a firework, police said.
item.content:encoded: A man was struck and killed in a hit-and-run crash Saturday in Lennox when he tripped in the street after lighting a firework, police said.

item.title: L.A.'s extreme fireworks bring terrible air quality, increased calls for fire service

item.description: Despite a ban on Fourth of July fireworks displays due to the coronavirus, L.A. firefighters responded to thousands of emergency calls on Saturday.
item.content:encoded: Despite a ban on Fourth of July fireworks displays due to the coronavirus, L.A. firefighters responded to thousands of emergency calls on Saturday.

media:content.media:description: BURBANK, CA - JULY 04: Fireworks over North Hollywood, as seen from Burbank on Saturday, July 4, 2020 in Burbank, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 10 spectacular scenes from Southern California's July 4 celebrations
item.dc:creator: Los Angeles Times Staff
item.description: The beaches were closed and many fireworks shows were canceled, but Southern California still celebrated July 4.
item.content:encoded: The beaches were closed and many fireworks shows were canceled, but Southern California still celebrated July 4.

media:content.media:description: LOS ALAMITOS, CA - JULY 4, 2020: Southern California residents sit on the roofs of their vehicles to watch the fireworks during the Drive-Up 4th of July Spectacular at the Los Alamitos Joint Forces Training Base during the coronavirus pandemic on July 4, 2020 in Los Alamitos, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Sunday morning at 5:17 a.m. Pacific time 27 miles from Alpine, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Sunday morning at 5:17 a.m. Pacific time 27 miles from Alpine, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: California megadrought? Not if you look at precipitation
item.dc:creator: Bettina Boxall
item.description: Climate change is increasing California's wet-to-dry extremes, but average precipitation is not declining.
item.content:encoded: Climate change is increasing California's wet-to-dry extremes, but average precipitation is not declining.

media:content.media:description: SANTA BARBARA, CA - MAY 20: The Bradbury Dam finished in 1953 across the Santa Ynez River forms Cachuma Lake, North of Santa Barbara, on May 20, 2020 which is over 80% full thanks to two good Southern California rainy seasons in a row. The 2020 rainy season helped the water supply in Southern California but it has played out very differently across the state: Parts of Northern California are experiencing the driest season on record, while the state's southeast corner is among the wettest on record. Cachuma Lake on Wednesday, May 20, 2020 in Santa Barbara, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'You started the corona!' As anti-Asian hate incidents explode, climbing past 800, activists push for aid
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: As more Californians report anti-Asian hate incidents, activists push Gov. Gavin Newsom for aid.
item.content:encoded: As more Californians report anti-Asian hate incidents, activists push Gov. Gavin Newsom for aid.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE COUNTY, CA - JULY 02: Donalene Ferrer, left, who is of Filipino ancestry, and her daughter, Charlie, 17, who is Filipino-Italian are photographed wearing protective masks near their home in Riverside County. In April, they were walking with Donalene's mother in Oceanside when the mother's neighbor yelled at them from her car, saying: "You started the corona." There has been an increase in hate incidents against Asians and Asian Americans, with their accusers unleashing accusations at people they blame for infecting "Americans" with COVID-19. Photos taken Thursday, July 2, 2020 in Riverside County, CA. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Do L.A. politicians who pushed for reopening now have regrets as coronavirus cases climb?
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: How will L.A. County move forward in combating the coronavirus outbreak? Leaders from the Board of Supervisors offer a mixed bag of answers.
item.content:encoded: How will L.A. County move forward in combating the coronavirus outbreak? Leaders from the Board of Supervisors offer a mixed bag of answers.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 01, 2020: Mary Granados, a waitress at The Original Pantry in Downtown Los Angeles, tapes a sign to the window letting customers know that they are now only open for take out service. California Gov. Gavin Newsom announced today that for the next 3 weeks, restaurants in Los Angeles County and a number of other counties statewide will only be allowed to have take out and delivery service due to an increase in coronavirus cases. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD responds to a million 911 calls a year, but relatively few for violent crimes
item.dc:creator: Joel Rubin, Ben Poston
item.description: A decade of 911 calls to the LAPD reviewed by The Times helps explain the possibilities and challenges of reimagining police.
item.content:encoded: A decade of 911 calls to the LAPD reviewed by The Times helps explain the possibilities and challenges of reimagining police.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 01: Los Angeles Police Headquarters located at First and Spring Street in downtown Los Angeles July 1, 2020 as Los Angeles City Council voted to cut hiring at the LAPD, pushing the number of sworn officers well below 10,000 and abandoning a budget priority once seen as untouchable by city leaders. LAPD Headquarters on Wednesday, July 1, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County sees 'alarming' rise in coronavirus hospitalizations, infection rates
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: In what officials Saturday described as an "alarming" increase, hospitalizations of patients with confirmed coronavirus infections in Los Angeles County have jumped 41% in the last three weeks.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - JULY 04: Mike Whitford, of Newport Beach, wearing Captain America costume, shown with his family and the Schmidgall Family, as the OneHB Neighborhood Parade passes by celebrating the Fourth of July with two vehicle caravans traveling on separate routes, passing within a mile of every single home in Huntington Beach, on Saturday, July 4, 2020 in Huntington Beach, CA. The 2020 Huntington Beach Main Street 4th of July Parade is modified and did not happen on Main Street due to Statewide COVID-19 restrictions on large events. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Death row inmate Scott Erskine, who murdered two boys in San Diego, dies of COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Greg Moran
item.description: The 57-year-old had been on death row since 2004 for murdering two boys he abducted and tortured in 1993. The case went unsolved for eight years.
item.content:encoded: The 57-year-old had been on death row since 2004 for murdering two boys he abducted and tortured in 1993. The case went unsolved for eight years.

item.dc:creator: Tomás Mier

item.title: Newsom vows crackdown on coronavirus scofflaws. Will law enforcement cooperate?
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom again Wednesday threatened more enforcement for businesses that fail to follow coronavirus guidance, but how it would work remains unclear
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom again Wednesday threatened more enforcement for businesses that fail to follow coronavirus guidance, but how it would work remains unclear

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this June 9, 2020 file photo Gov. Gavin Newsom wears a protective mask on his face while speaking to reporters at Miss Ollie's restaurant during the coronavirus outbreak in Oakland, Calif. Newsom said Wednesday, June 23, 2020, that he will leverage $2.5 billion in the upcoming state budget to penalize counties that fail to comply with the state's mandates on wearing masks, testing and other measures meant to slow the spread of the coronavirus. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu, Pool, File)

item.title: On this Independence Day as coronavirus cases surge, please remember our interdependence

item.description: Freedom means getting through the coronavirus together, not refusing to wear masks or to take the virus seriously
item.content:encoded: Freedom means getting through the coronavirus together, not refusing to wear masks or to take the virus seriously

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 02: People walk through the Universal CityWalk, just outside of the Universal Studios Theme park on Thursday, July 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As Southern California sees a surge in confirmed cases of COVID19 tied to business re-openings, social gatherings and other factors and hospitals are becoming increasingly crowded. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Lancaster set to defy L.A. County's ban on Fourth of July fireworks
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: The Lancaster City Council has called an emergency meeting Saturday to vote on whether to defy a Los Angeles countywide ban on fireworks displays over the July Fourth weekend.
item.content:encoded: The Lancaster City Council has called an emergency meeting Saturday to vote on whether to defy a Los Angeles countywide ban on fireworks displays over the July Fourth weekend.

media:content.media:description: Bryan Chan 8056537527   PASADENA0704Willie Zamora waves a flag as he watches the Rose Bowl Taste of America fireworks show in Pasadena.Times Photo by Bryan Chan

item.title: Beaches close across California for Fourth of July weekend as coronavirus cases surge
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza, Kiera Feldman
item.description: As beach closures went into effect to stem the spread of the coronavirus over the Fourth of July weekend, Southern Californians mostly followed the rules on Friday.
item.content:encoded: As beach closures went into effect to stem the spread of the coronavirus over the Fourth of July weekend, Southern Californians mostly followed the rules on Friday.

media:content.media:description: MANHATTAN BEACH, CA - JULY 03: A bicyclist rides along Highland Ave. with the pier closed to beachgoers on Friday, July 3, 2020 in Manhattan Beach, CA. Los Angeles County Closes Beaches, Piers, Beach Parking Lots, Beach Bike Paths, and Beach Access Points for the Fourth of July Weekend due to Increased COVID-19 Cases. Closed from Friday, July 3rd at 12:00 A.M. thru Monday, July 6th at 5:00 A.M. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Truck driver posts regrets about party a day before dying of coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.description: Riverside County truck driver Tommy Macias died of COVID-19 after attending a barbecue. His final message was a warning filled with regret.
item.content:encoded: Riverside County truck driver Tommy Macias died of COVID-19 after attending a barbecue. His final message was a warning filled with regret.

media:content.media:description: Alessandra Zaragoza and Tommy Macias posing during lunch in 2017. (Courtesy of Danielle Lopez)

item.title: Consulting firm accuses city of L.A. of concealing evidence in DWP billing case
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: Consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers is seeking at least $8 million, alleging the city tried to conceal evidence during legal proceedings.
item.content:encoded: Consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers is seeking at least $8 million, alleging the city tried to conceal evidence during legal proceedings.

media:content.media:description: The Department of Water and Power building in Los Angeles. An audit shows at least a $681-million shortfall in the agency's billing.

item.title: Santa Barbara grand jury blasts county supervisors over marijuana industry
item.dc:creator: Joe Mozingo
item.description: A Santa Barbara grand jury blames county supervisors for working too closely with lobbyists as they sought to regulate massive marijuana grows
item.content:encoded: A Santa Barbara grand jury blames county supervisors for working too closely with lobbyists as they sought to regulate massive marijuana grows

media:content.media:description: CARPINTERIA, CA - MAY 06, 2019 -Marijuana growing in a steel-frame greenhouse at Brand Farms in Carpinteria at the southern end of Santa Barbara County that has allowed some of the biggest marijuana grows in the world. Lobbied by the marijuana industry, Santa Barbara County officials opened the door to big cannabis interest in the last two years like no other county in the nation, setting off a largely unregulated rush of planting in a region not previously known for the crop. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: COVID-19 silenced this singing activist, but not her spirit
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.description: Albia Miller, 71, is the singing gadfly of Riverside County. The dreaded coronavirus pulled the curtain down on most of her stages
item.content:encoded: Albia Miller, 71, is the singing gadfly of Riverside County. The dreaded coronavirus pulled the curtain down on most of her stages

media:content.media:description: MENIFEE, CA - JUNE 24, 2020: Activists Albia Miller sits on the lush green lawn under a canopy of shade trees at the Menifee Valley Campus, where she normally spends many hours at the library nearby, but the library is now closed due to COVID-19 on June 24, 2020 in Menifee, California. She frequents most council meetings to oppose development projects in Riverside County and many times can be heard singing original songs during her opposition. But, due to COVID-19 she is unable to share her tunes.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's July 4 coronavirus warning: 'Assume everyone around you is infectious'
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee, Sean Greene
item.description: The rate at which coronavirus tests in California are coming back positive continues its alarming climb — jumping 51% over the past two weeks, a Los Angeles Times analysis found.
item.content:encoded: The rate at which coronavirus tests in California are coming back positive continues its alarming climb — jumping 51% over the past two weeks, a Los Angeles Times analysis found.

media:content.media:description: MANHATTAN BEACH, CA - JULY 02: Scenes from Manhattan Beach, CA, looking north, on Thursday, July 2, 2020, the day before Los Angeles County beaches close for the July 4th holiday, under order from California Gov. Gavin Newsom, in an effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Under siege by a virus that thrives in crowds, L.A. swap meets face a reckoning
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: In a new world where crowds mean danger, swap meets and the vendors who make them run struggle to stay afloat.
item.content:encoded: In a new world where crowds mean danger, swap meets and the vendors who make them run struggle to stay afloat.

media:content.media:description: SANTA FE SPRINGS, CA - JUNE 20: Claudio Eclicerio, 51, organizes fruits at his stand at the Santa Fe Springs Swap Meet on Saturday, June 20, 2020 in Santa Fe Springs, CA. Swap Meets across the Southland are struggling to bounce back after finally re-opening amid the ongoing Coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Former L.A. building official alleges he was ousted after blowing whistle on fraud
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes

item.title: Californians are losing their fear of the coronavirus, setting the stage for disaster
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Sean Greene
item.description: The public has become more accustomed to the COVID-19 pandemic, but the virus is no less infectious now than it was in the winter.
item.content:encoded: The public has become more accustomed to the COVID-19 pandemic, but the virus is no less infectious now than it was in the winter.

media:content.media:description: ##PATIENT PROVIDED VERBAL CONSENT TO HOSPITAL REPRESENTATIVES## CHULA VISTA, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 2020: RN Arnold Garcia collects a sample for a coronavirus test from Michael Weiss after he was admitted with possible COVID-19 symptoms at Sharp Chula Vista Medical Center in Chula Vista, Calif., on April 10, 2020. On the left, RN Shauna Stanfill supervises. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: The 4.5 earthquake occurred at 2:20 a.m. on Hawaii's Big Island.
item.content:encoded: The 4.5 earthquake occurred at 2:20 a.m. on Hawaii's Big Island.

item.content:encoded: Rain year in L.A. was near-average, but far from normal

media:content.media:description: Downtown Los Angeles seen from Boyle Heights on a rainy late-winter day.

item.title: Orange County inflated its coronavirus test numbers by mistakenly including antibody tests, officials say
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The total number of COVID-19 tests conducted in Orange County was mistakenly inflated for more than a month beginning in late April in data released to the public, an error that may have painted a rosier picture of the pandemic than the reality in the region.
item.content:encoded: The total number of COVID-19 tests conducted in Orange County was mistakenly inflated for more than a month beginning in late April in data released to the public, an error that may have painted a rosier picture of the pandemic than the reality in the region.

media:content.media:description: WILMINGTON, CA - JUNE 25: Truck driver Jose Lopez, 64, gets a free COVID-19 nasal swab test administered by Nurse Practitioner Alexander Panis, left, as truck drivers working at the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach take advantage of testing Thursday. The truck drivers union alleges many of the port truck drivers' employers have not been providing proper personal protective equipment and testing priority will be given to drivers to keep workers safe in the era of Coronavirus. Wilmington on Thursday, June 25, 2020 in Wilmington, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County's new $0 bail rule permits police to crack down on protesters, legal advocates say
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Several exemptions to L.A. County's $0 bail rule permit police departments to hold people for misdemeanor offenses commonly associated with protests, including unlawful assembly and failure to disperse.
item.content:encoded: Several exemptions to L.A. County's $0 bail rule permit police departments to hold people for misdemeanor offenses commonly associated with protests, including unlawful assembly and failure to disperse.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 2, 2020: Arrests made for curfew vilotation after a day of peaceful protest against police brutality and to demonstrate in Los Angeles, CA. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: San Francisco cracks down on archdiocese for violating coronavirus rules
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Church officials have agreed to stop celebrating public Mass indoors and to restrict outdoor services after the city attorney sent a cease-and-desist letter.
item.content:encoded: Church officials have agreed to stop celebrating public Mass indoors and to restrict outdoor services after the city attorney sent a cease-and-desist letter.

media:content.media:description: Salvatore Cordileone has been named Roman Catholic archbishop-elect of San Francisco.

item.title: Its two hospitals overrun, Imperial County halts in-store retail and indoor religious services
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: The Imperial County health order also closes all county parks, bars gatherings and directs residents to stay at home when possible. Over 20% of coronavirus tests in the county come back positive.
item.content:encoded: The Imperial County health order also closes all county parks, bars gatherings and directs residents to stay at home when possible. Over 20% of coronavirus tests in the county come back positive.

media:content.media:description: Un hombre camina frente a una tienda el martes 30 de junio de 2020, en Calexico, California. (AP Foto/Gregory Bull)

item.title: California lawmakers take quick action to advance expansion of paid family leave
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: California Senate passes a bill to provide job protections to employees of small businesses. But some say the protections will hurt those businesses.
item.content:encoded: California Senate passes a bill to provide job protections to employees of small businesses. But some say the protections will hurt those businesses.

media:content.media:description: State Sen. Hannah-Beth Jackson, D-Santa Barbara, urges lawmakers to approve her measure to expand job protections to more people who take time off to care for a family member during the Senate session at the Capitol in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, July 2, 2020. By a 21-12 the Senate approved the measure that will allow workers at companies with at least five employees up to three months off from work to care for a family member without fear of losing their jobs. The bill now goes to the Assembly. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: County-run beaches in O.C. will close July 4th weekend as coronavirus cases surge
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Hillary Davis, Lilly Nguyen
item.description: A dozen Orange County-operated beaches join a growing list of city shorelines that will close in an effort to keep crowds from congregating and potentially spreading the virus.
item.content:encoded: A dozen Orange County-operated beaches join a growing list of city shorelines that will close in an effort to keep crowds from congregating and potentially spreading the virus.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - JUNE 10: Beach goers recreate at the water's edge to cool off amid high temperatures Wednesday, June 10, 2020 in Huntington Beach, CA. A heat advisory will be in effect today from 11 in the morning until 7 tonight throughout Southern California. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'A heroic act': Teen drowns after rescuing 12-year-old friend at Northern California lake
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: The drowning was the second in Calaveras County in the last two weeks.
item.content:encoded: The drowning was the second in Calaveras County in the last two weeks.

media:content.media:description: IONE, CA - AUGUST 08: Low water levels are visible at Camanche Reservoir on August 8, 2014 in Ione, California. As the severe drought in California contiues to worsen, the majority of the State's major reservoirs are at or below 50 percent of capacity with some nearing the 20 percent mark. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.title: The coronavirus has changed since it left Wuhan. Is it more infectious?
item.dc:creator: Ralph Vartabedian
item.description: A newer strain of the coronavirus has a mutation that might make it more infectious, a team of scientists says. Other researchers disagree.
item.content:encoded: A newer strain of the coronavirus has a mutation that might make it more infectious, a team of scientists says. Other researchers disagree.

media:content.media:description: An atomic resolution 3-D model of the novel coronavirus, SARS-Cov-2.

item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Maura Dolan, Phil Willon
item.description: The new tool was released as L.A., like many areas in California and the U.S., sees distressing spikes in COVID-19 infections and hospitalizations.
item.content:encoded: The new tool was released as L.A., like many areas in California and the U.S., sees distressing spikes in COVID-19 infections and hospitalizations.

item.title: Cities race to close beaches for Fourth of July holiday as coronavirus surges
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Stephanie Lai, Hillary Davis, Lilly Nguyen
item.description: Los Angeles and Ventura counties will close beaches for the entire holiday weekend, while several Orange County cities will close their shores Saturday.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles and Ventura counties will close beaches for the entire holiday weekend, while several Orange County cities will close their shores Saturday.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - JUNE 10: Beach goers take to the water to cool off amid high temperatures Wednesday, June 10, 2020 in Huntington Beach, CA. A heat advisory will be in effect today from 11 in the morning until 7 tonight throughout Southern California. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Beyond horrible': Tiny desert town devastated by wildfire as it battles the coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.description: A wildfire in the Imperial County town of Niland cost dozens of families their homes during the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: A wildfire in the Imperial County town of Niland cost dozens of families their homes during the COVID-19 pandemic.

media:content.media:description: Ana Valenzuela stares at the pile of ashes and debris where her home used to be on June 30, 2020 in Niland, California. On top of a spike in pandemic activity, several residents in the Imperial County town of Niland have been displaced from their homes after a fire swept through the community.
media:content.media:credit: Eduardo Contreras / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: USC reverses robust fall reopening plans, asks students to stay home for online classes
item.dc:creator: Tomás Mier
item.description: Only 10% to 20% of classes will be offered in person and on campus, reversing USC's original decision to reopen for the fall semester.
item.content:encoded: Only 10% to 20% of classes will be offered in person and on campus, reversing USC's original decision to reopen for the fall semester.

media:content.media:description: USC officials attribute rising tuition to the cost of attracting top faculty and making campus improvements.

item.title: Not wearing a mask could cost you hundreds in Westside as officials pledge enforcement
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Stephanie Lai
item.description: The sheriff's station will issue citations to those not following the statewide coronavirus health order to don face coverings while in public or high-risk settings.
item.content:encoded: The sheriff's station will issue citations to those not following the statewide coronavirus health order to don face coverings while in public or high-risk settings.

media:content.media:description: West Hollywood CA. JULY 2, 2020 - A man wearing a face covering crosses San Vicente Blvd. at Santa Monica Blvd. in West Hollywood Thursday July 2, 2020. The Los Angeles Sheriff's Department will start ticketing people without masks. Sheriff's deputies in West Hollywood say they'll begin fining people spotted without a face covering in public. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Coronavirus at 'critical juncture' as hospitalizations in California soar
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Hannah Fry
item.description: After four daily infection records in the last two weeks, officials fear social gatherings could bring even more outbreaks over the July 4 weekend.
item.content:encoded: After four daily infection records in the last two weeks, officials fear social gatherings could bring even more outbreaks over the July 4 weekend.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 30, Shoppers, wearing masks to protect themselves from coronavirus, shop on Santee Alley in the Garment District in downtown Los Angeles on June 30, 2020. Masks are required for shopping on Santee Alley and social distancing is advised, but hard to enforce. The shopping area has been open again for the past three weeks. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. ice cream vendor adapts to life in a COVID-19 world
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda
item.description: For the past 16 years, Mauro Rios Parra has sold fruit bars and ice cream on the streets of Pico-Union, one of L.A.'s densest cities and among the hardest hit by the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: For the past 16 years, Mauro Rios Parra has sold fruit bars and ice cream on the streets of Pico-Union, one of L.A.'s densest cities and among the hardest hit by the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 16: Mauro Rios Parra sells a paleta to Matthew Chicas, 6, who has been purchasing from him his entire life on Tuesday, June 16, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Parra came to the U.S. from Mexico about 20 years ago to financially support his wife and three kids in Oaxaca and he has been selling paletas ever since. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In California, the death penalty is all but meaningless. A life sentence for the Golden State Killer was the right move
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: "He is the real-life version of Hannibal Lecter," Sacramento County Dist. Atty. Anne Marie Schubert told reporters
item.content:encoded: "He is the real-life version of Hannibal Lecter," Sacramento County Dist. Atty. Anne Marie Schubert told reporters

media:content.media:description: Sacramento County Sheriff's Deputies use a wheelchair to bring Joseph James DeAngelo into the courtroom in Sacramento Superior Court in Sacramento, Calif. Monday, June 29, 2020. DeAngelo, 74, pleaded guilty to 13 counts of murder and multiple other charges 40 years after a sadistic series of assaults and slayings in California. Due to the large numbers of people attending, the hearing was held at a ballroom at California State University, Sacramento to allow for social distancing. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Coronavirus fears spook Queen Mary into canceling Dark Harbor haunt
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: The popular spooky spectacle has been called off for 2020 as the pandemic continues, but is set to return in 2021.
item.content:encoded: The popular spooky spectacle has been called off for 2020 as the pandemic continues, but is set to return in 2021.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CALIF. - OCTOBER 05, 2017: Monsters wait for the gates to open to greet guests at Queen Mary's Dark Harbor Halloween celebration. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Coronavirus 'curve is no longer flat' in Riverside County, official says
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: As coronavirus cases and hospitalizations rise in Riverside County, health officials say that the "curve is no longer flat."
item.content:encoded: As coronavirus cases and hospitalizations rise in Riverside County, health officials say that the "curve is no longer flat."

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 3, 2020: Adeline Hernandez, 2, of Riverside seems perplexed by the yellow caution tape as she approaches the closed off swing sets during the coronavirus pandemic at Ryan Bonaminio Park on April 3, 2020 in Riverside, California. She was visiting the park with her dad Erick Hernandez. All the playground equipment and drinking fountains are closed off with yellow caution tape.(Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Gina Ferazzi/Gina Ferazzi/Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Two girls, man killed in apparent murder-suicide in Watts, L.A. police say
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Two girls and a man died in a Watts home in what police are calling a murder-suicide. The girls died in the home from undisclosed injuries.
item.content:encoded: Two girls and a man died in a Watts home in what police are calling a murder-suicide. The girls died in the home from undisclosed injuries.

item.title: Music teacher linked to semen-tainted flutes pleads guilty to child pornography charges
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: John Zeretzke, linked to flutes contaminated with semen that were then given to schoolchildren, pleaded guilty to one charge of production of child pornography.
item.content:encoded: John Zeretzke, linked to flutes contaminated with semen that were then given to schoolchildren, pleaded guilty to one charge of production of child pornography.

item.title: Here are the 12 propositions on California's November ballot

item.description: Eight measures earned a spot on the Nov. 3 ballot through the collection of voter signatures. Four were added by the California Legislature.
item.content:encoded: Eight measures earned a spot on the Nov. 3 ballot through the collection of voter signatures. Four were added by the California Legislature.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 4, 2019: A voter checks her ballot while voting at Silver Lake Recreation Center on June 4, 2019 in Los Angeles, California. Voters are deciding on the schools tax by LAUSD Measure EE and LA City Council election for District 12.(Gina Ferazzi/Los AngelesTimes)

item.title: As coronavirus cases surge, L.A. postpones plans to ticket during street sweeping
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: Los Angeles will not ticket vehicles that are parked in rush-hour and anti-gridlock zones or in residential areas during street sweeping until Aug. 1 at the earliest.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles will not ticket vehicles that are parked in rush-hour and anti-gridlock zones or in residential areas during street sweeping until Aug. 1 at the earliest.

media:content.media:description: A car off Hawthorn Avenue in Hollywood is ticketed on street-sweeping day.

item.title: What to know as California halts indoor dining, shutters other businesses
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: Newsom orders counties to halt visits to indoor restaurants, wineries, entertainment centers, movie theaters, zoos and museums for at least three weeks.
item.content:encoded: Newsom orders counties to halt visits to indoor restaurants, wineries, entertainment centers, movie theaters, zoos and museums for at least three weeks.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CALIFORNIA MAY 23, 2020-Diners enjoy a meal at BusyBee 50's Cafe in Ventura Saturday. The county lifted a lockdown for sit down dining at all restaurants.(Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A rural Northern California county had few COVID-19 cases, until an inmate transfer led to a large prison outbreak
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: There were just a handful of coronavirus cases in rural Lassen County in Northern California until an outbreak at a prison in Susanville. Health officials say it began after inmates from San Quentin Prison were transferred to the facility.
item.content:encoded: There were just a handful of coronavirus cases in rural Lassen County in Northern California until an outbreak at a prison in Susanville. Health officials say it began after inmates from San Quentin Prison were transferred to the facility.

media:content.media:description: The California Correctional Center in Susanville, at top, adjoins the High Desert State Prison in Lassen County.
media:content.media:credit: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

item.title: Real estate firm puts executive on leave amid Jose Huizar pay-to-play probe
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes

item.content:encoded: A real estate firm puts one of its executives on leave amid the federal corruption probe that led to the arrest of L.A. City Councilman Jose Huizar.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles City Councilman Jose Huizar, shown at a council meeting in February, has been accused by a former aide of sexual harassment.

item.title: Orange County restaurants close for cleaning as coronavirus cases continue to climb
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: A handful of Orange County restaurants have temporarily closed in the last week to deep clean and sanitize their spaces, some after discovering that employees had been infected with COVID-19, business owners said.
item.content:encoded: A handful of Orange County restaurants have temporarily closed in the last week to deep clean and sanitize their spaces, some after discovering that employees had been infected with COVID-19, business owners said.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA, July 26, 2016 -- Seating area below Old Crow Smokehouse at Pacific City in Huntington Beach. (Kevin Chang/ Huntington Beach Independent)

item.title: L.A. revamps rules for cannabis licensing, hoping to redress harm from war on drugs
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: L.A. is revamping its rules for handing out licenses to cannabis businesses amid anger and disappointment over the tumultuous rollout of the program.
item.content:encoded: L.A. is revamping its rules for handing out licenses to cannabis businesses amid anger and disappointment over the tumultuous rollout of the program.

media:content.media:description: Cat Packer, executive director of the Los Angeles Department of Cannabis Regulation, addresses Los Angeles City Council member Curren Price, foreground, before the council voted unanimously to approve new regulations for the marijuana industry, on Wednesday, Dec. 6, 2017, in Los Angeles. (AP Photo/Chris Pizzello)

item.title: Restaurant dining rooms, wineries, card rooms to close for at least three weeks in 19 California counties
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Phil Willon
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom restricts indoor dining, tasting rooms, entertainment centers, movie theaters, zoos, museums and card rooms in California counties struggling to control the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom restricts indoor dining, tasting rooms, entertainment centers, movie theaters, zoos, museums and card rooms in California counties struggling to control the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 01, 2020 - - Waiter Pedro Armenta, wearing a face shield and mask, cleans menus inside the deserted dining area of Dupar's Restaurant which is still receiving customers for patio dining and take-out service at the Original Farmers Market in the Fairfax District in Los Angeles on July 1, 2020. California Governor Gavin Newsom ordered indoor restaurants closed effective immediately on July 1, 2020. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Los Angeles cuts LAPD spending, taking police staffing to its lowest level in 12 years
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith, Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Deluged by demands for cuts in police spending, the L.A. City Council votes to take the LAPD down to 9,757 officers by next summer.
item.content:encoded: Deluged by demands for cuts in police spending, the L.A. City Council votes to take the LAPD down to 9,757 officers by next summer.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 01: Los Angeles Police Headquarters located at First and Spring Street in downtown Los Angeles July 1, 2020 as Los Angeles City Council voted to cut hiring at the LAPD, pushing the number of sworn officers well below 10,000 and abandoning a budget priority once seen as untouchable by city leaders. LAPD Headquarters on Wednesday, July 1, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Offensive behavior by 'All Lives Matter' group against Black protesters sparks concerns, Norco officials say
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: Norco sets a 6 a.m.-to-6 p.m. curfew after a Black Lives Matter rally and march are disrupted by counterprotesters.
item.content:encoded: Norco sets a 6 a.m.-to-6 p.m. curfew after a Black Lives Matter rally and march are disrupted by counterprotesters.

item.title: Orange County must close bars, indoor restaurants amid coronavirus surge
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Newsom announced that Orange County and 18 other counties must immediately close bars and cease indoor operations at restaurants, wineries and more.
item.content:encoded: Newsom announced that Orange County and 18 other counties must immediately close bars and cease indoor operations at restaurants, wineries and more.

media:content.media:description: PLACENTIA, CA - MAY 16: Bartender Brianna Van De Mortel takes a beer order from a customer at Kelly's Korner on Saturday, May 16, 2020 in Placentia, CA. The sports bar is effectively grounded as the pandemic shutdowns affecting all restaurants limit them to take-out. Like most restaurants and bars, Kelly's has had to pivot drastically to survive. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County to shutter indoor dining at restaurants amid coronavirus spike
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Rong-Gong Lin II, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom orders the immediate closure of bars, restaurants and other indoor facilities in 19 counties as COVID-19 cases spike.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom orders the immediate closure of bars, restaurants and other indoor facilities in 19 counties as COVID-19 cases spike.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 06: J.T. McDermott, 27, and Marissa Robbins, 26 get their meal delivered to the "landing-zone" by servers Alex Avila and Joshua Hernandez, at Faith & Flower in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday, June 6, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As restrictions are lifted and businesses and the economy start to re-open, restaurants are putting in place rules to ensure proper social distancing and the health and safety of guests. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus and financial hurdles are delaying projects to build homeless housing
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: More than six months after Mayor Eric Garcetti predicted that a new housing project for homeless people would open every three weeks, there has been only one other opening to celebrate. The coronavirus pandemic is one reason for the delay -- but only one.
item.content:encoded: More than six months after Mayor Eric Garcetti predicted that a new housing project for homeless people would open every three weeks, there has been only one other opening to celebrate. The coronavirus pandemic is one reason for the delay -- but only one.

media:content.media:description: PATH (People Assisting The Homeless) Metro Villas Phase 2 under construction in 2019 with Proposition HHH funding as an affordable, supportive housing community.

item.title: He worked hard to find a job after a nonprofit paid his bail. Then the coronavirus hit
item.dc:creator: Marisa Gerber
item.description: When Tomajae Tolliver thought about COVID-19, the economy and his job, a question looped through his mind: "How am I going to survive?"
item.content:encoded: When Tomajae Tolliver thought about COVID-19, the economy and his job, a question looped through his mind: "How am I going to survive?"

media:content.media:description: COMPTON, CA - JUNE 03: Priscilia Martinez, left, with the Compton chapter of the Bail Project, delivers supplies to recently releases client Tomajae Tolliver, right, and his pregnant girlfriend Katherine Cordova, center, at the home of Tolliver's mother where he lives on Wednesday, June 3, 2020 in Compton, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: California fears July 4 coronavirus disaster, plans new restrictions
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Jake Sheridan, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: State and local governments plan more restrictions as coronavirus cases continue to spike in California.
item.content:encoded: State and local governments plan more restrictions as coronavirus cases continue to spike in California.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA - JUNE 30: Kids ride a wave together as they learn to surf on a warm summer day at the San Clemente Pier Tuesday, June 30, 2020. Heal the Bay released its annual Beach Report Card and the San Clemente Pier made the top 10 list of beach bummers. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: As coronavirus cases surge, California pauses multimillion-dollar testing expansion
item.dc:creator: Angela Hart, Rachel Bluth
item.description: California is cutting off funding for COVID-19 testing just when counties say they need more resources in rural and disadvantaged areas.
item.content:encoded: California is cutting off funding for COVID-19 testing just when counties say they need more resources in rural and disadvantaged areas.

media:content.media:description: CARSON, CA - APRIL 28, 2020 - - Carson City Mayor Albert Robles does self-testing at a new drive-up testing site for COVID-19 outside the East Wing of the Congresswoman Juanita Millender-McDonald Community Center in Carson on April 28, 2020. Free COVID-19 testing is available to all city residents thanks to a partnership between the city and US Health Fairs. Carson is the first Southern California city to offer free testing to all its residents. Mayor Robles and members of the City Council were joined by Assemblyman Mike A. Gipson, D-Carson, for the test site opening. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Protests over police brutality and criminal justice reform intensify race for L.A. district attorney
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: The battle between Jackie Lacey and George Gascón to lead the nation's largest local district attorney's office is already being influenced by the fallout of national calls to change American policing.
item.content:encoded: The battle between Jackie Lacey and George Gascón to lead the nation's largest local district attorney's office is already being influenced by the fallout of national calls to change American policing.

media:content.media:description: Left, Los Angeles County District Attorney Jackie Lacey during a press conference at the Hall of Justice in Los Angeles, Calif., on Nov. 15, 2019. Right, former San Francisco District Attorney George Gascon took part in the debate at the California African-American Museum on Wednesday, Dec. 11, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times

item.title: A third day of coronavirus surges in L.A. County brings alarm
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Luke Money
item.description: Coronavirus keeps raging in L.A. County, other parts of California. The state as a whole hit a grim milestone Tuesday when it exceeded 6,000 deaths.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus keeps raging in L.A. County, other parts of California. The state as a whole hit a grim milestone Tuesday when it exceeded 6,000 deaths.

media:content.media:description: HERMOSA BEACH, CA --MARCH 28, 2020 - Signs and barricades let people know of the closures of The Strand and the beach in Hermosa Beach, CA., as part of Los Angeles County's closures, in an effort to prevent crowds and gatherings of people and slow the spread of the coronavirus, March 28, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Column: On this California beach, snowy plovers and dune buggies are in a fight for survival
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: Environmentalists would like to see Oceano Dunes closed to off-road vehicles to protect nesting birds. Off-roaders consider themselves the endangered species.
item.content:encoded: Environmentalists would like to see Oceano Dunes closed to off-road vehicles to protect nesting birds. Off-roaders consider themselves the endangered species.

media:content.media:description: OCEANO, CA - JULY 03, 2019 - The Oceano Dunes, a few miles south of Pismo Beach off Highway 1, are a major destination for off-roaders and campers, the bulk of them driving in from the Central Valley, Greater Los Angeles or the Bay Area. They arrive in trucks, trailers and RVs and other vehicles, motoring down a ramp onto the beach to access the âSand Highway,â to make camp July 3, 2019. Oceano Dunes State Park, one of the stateâs most popular parks draws about 2 million visitors a year. On busy weekends and holidays, reservations for its 1,000 sandy campsites fill up six months in advance. The California Coastal Commission is considering a move to scale back, and potentially eliminate, off-roading at the Oceano Dunes, the only state park on the California coast where you can still ride off-road vehicles. The decision stems from decades of controversy over off roading's impact on sensitive dune habitat, endangered birds and air quality for nearby residents. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. Unified police chief resigns after district slashes department budget
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Sonali Kohli
item.description: The Los Angeles School board voted to defund the school police budget by $25 million following weeks of protests by student activists involved in the Black Lives Matter movement.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles School board voted to defund the school police budget by $25 million following weeks of protests by student activists involved in the Black Lives Matter movement.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 23: Los Angeles School Board member Monica Garcia prepares before the LAUSD Board Zoom meeting at headquarters as members of Black Lives Matter-Los Angeles and their supporters held a demonstration outside LAUSD headquarters to demand that the Board of Education defund school police, reallocating funds to other student-serving initiatives. Los Angeles on Tuesday, June 23, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: At least 176 test positive for coronavirus at Ventura County farmworker housing complex
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: Of the 216 tests administered to residents and staff at the facility, more than 80% have come back positive for COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Of the 216 tests administered to residents and staff at the facility, more than 80% have come back positive for COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: OXNARD, CA-DECEMBER 22, 2017: Farm workers pick strawberries in a field in Oxnard on December 22, 2017. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newsom warns of more coronavirus restrictions and enforcement ahead of July 4 weekend
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom on Wednesday ordered tougher restrictions on indoor activities for most of the state, marking a major step backward in the reopening and an attempt to slow an alarming rise of the coronavirus in 19 counties.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom on Wednesday ordered tougher restrictions on indoor activities for most of the state, marking a major step backward in the reopening and an attempt to slow an alarming rise of the coronavirus in 19 counties.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 15: A bicylist rides past the latest mural created by Mr. Brainwash that tells Americans to remain hopeful in the time of the coronavirus pandemic in Los Angeles on June 15, 2020. Venice on Monday, June 15, 2020 Los Angeles, CA. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Times sues L.A. County sheriff over withholding records on deputy misconduct
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: The Los Angeles Times has filed a lawsuit against Los Angeles County, alleging that the Sheriff's Department has repeatedly refused to turn over public records about deputies involved in misconduct or shootings.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles Times has filed a lawsuit against Los Angeles County, alleging that the Sheriff's Department has repeatedly refused to turn over public records about deputies involved in misconduct or shootings.

media:content.media:description: A union representing sheriff's deputies on Tuesday sought unsuccessfully to block a newspaper from publishing information from officers' background checks.

item.title: Citing coronavirus concerns, Ventura County closes beaches for 4th of July weekend
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Ventura County health officials announced they were following Los Angeles County in closing beaches for the 4th of July holiday weekend to limit the spread of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Ventura County health officials announced they were following Los Angeles County in closing beaches for the 4th of July holiday weekend to limit the spread of COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 02: Beaches including Harbor Cove Beach were open but beachgoers were not supposed to be sitting on the sand on Saturday, May 2, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. calls restraining order on LAPD use of batons and projectiles 'unwarranted'
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Richard Winton
item.description: Attorneys for Los Angeles on Tuesday argued against a temporary restraining order to block police from using batons and tactical bullets to control crowds.
item.content:encoded: Attorneys for Los Angeles on Tuesday argued against a temporary restraining order to block police from using batons and tactical bullets to control crowds.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Tuesday, June 2, 2020 - A phalanx of LAPD officers rush to arrest dozens of George Floyd protesters who were violating curfew laws on Broadway. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)
